author: Ruth Ann Krause
title: Councilman requests bail on murder charge - Post-Tribune
text:
An East Chicago city councilman up for re-election Nov. 3 will spend Election Day in a cell at the Lake County Jail.
Defense attorney John Cantrell on Tuesday requested bail for Robert C. Battle, 42, a Democrat who represents the East Chicago's 3rd District, in Judge Clarence Murray's courtroom in Lake Superior Court.
Battle, who has pleaded not guilty, was charged last week with murder in the death of Reimundo Camarillo Jr., 31, of East Chicago, who was shot once in the back, court records state.
No dates have been set for the bail hearings, which will be heard by one of two criminal court magistrates. Battle's omnibus hearing is Dec. 8.
At about 8:20 a.m. Oct. 12, police were called to 142nd Street and Euclid Avenue in East Chicago regarding shots fired. An officer found a man later identified as Camarillo lying face down in an alley in the 4200 block of Euclid Avenue with blood coming from his nose, court documents said.
In response to contact from attorney Walter Alvarez, police went to his office after learning that Battle, of 4228 Euclid Ave., East Chicago, wanted to surrender. East Chicago police detectives, ATF and DEA agents and an Indiana State Police investigator were in the office when Alvarez said Battle would not give a statement, but that Alvarez would tell police what Battle had told him happened at his house, documents said.

(Teresa Auch Schultz) Alvarez said "Rey" and "Robert" were talking inside the home at 4228 Euclid Ave., according to court documents, when the conversation moved outside the home and into the alley. At some point, "Rey" started patting down "Robert," then pulled out a knife, records state. Battle shot "Rey" in response to the knife being produced, records state.
Through Alvarez, Battle indicated he used a .40-caliber handgun to shoot Camarillo and "threw" the gun somewhere in his home, records state. Neither a gun nor shell casings, bullet fragments or bullets were recovered at the scene or inside the Euclid Avenue home.
Ruth Ann Krause is a freelance reporter for the Post-Tribune.
